column1: '''''English and Welsh''''' is the title of [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]'s
inauguration speech for the O'Donnell Lectures.<ref>[[John Garth]]
column3: in ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien Encyclopedia: Scholarship and Critical Assessment]]''</ref> Tolkien presented the paper on [[21 October]] [[1955]] at the [[University of Oxford]].<ref>[[Wayne G. Hammond]] and [[Christina Scull]]
column4: ''[[The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide]]: Reader's Guide'' (2006)

column1: The lecture was first published in ''[[Angles and Britons|Angles and Britons: O'Donnell Lectures]]'' ([[8 July]] [[1963]]). In [[1983]]
column2: it was reprinted in ''[[The Monsters and the Critics and Other Essays]]''.
Tolkien discusses his notions of "native tongue" as opposed to "cradle tongue"
column3: and of an inherited taste of language. The lecture sheds light on Tolkien's conceptions of the connections of race
